awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: High-Speed Slitless Spectroscopy Studies of Natural Lightning Flashes
awd_abstract_narration:
Lightning flashes kill many people each year and damage power grids and electronic equipment in businesses and homes.  One of the greatest mysteries about lightning is how a flash initiates.  We know that the initiation processes turn non-conducting air into a short, thin conductor called the lightning channel, but it is not known exactly what physical mechanisms cause the first sparks of a lightning flash nor when these sparks produce the conducting channel.  This project will collect new data on lightning initiation using three high-speed video cameras and seven electric field change sensors.  The main societal impact of this research will be to improve our knowledge of lightning initiation and, potentially, save lives through improved lightning warning systems resulting from this research.  

The data collection will focus on the initial sparks (with durations of only 5 to 60 millionths of a second) that occur during the time needed to form the lightning channel, roughly the first 3 to 10 thousandths of a second of a lightning flash. The video cameras will record the development the initial pulses using frame rates of 100,000 to 300,000 frames/second, higher than previously used to study lightning initiation.  To determine whether the initial pulse channel is hot enough to be a good conductor (i.e. stepped leader) spectra acquired at 20 micro-seconds resolution or better will be used to measure the temperature development as a function of time during the initial stage and during the return stroke.  Data with up to 5 micro-second resolution and better sensitivity will also be used to study the more complicated behavior that seems to have been seen in the research group's earlier work and to compare cloud-to-ground (CG) and intercloud (IC) flash initiation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
One of the greatest mysteries about lightning is how it initiates inside clouds. It is known that the initiation processes turn non-conducting air into a thin, conducting lightning channel, but the physical mechanisms causing the first sparks of a lightning flash and the amount of time it takes for these sparks to produce the conducting channel remain unknown.

This project collected a new type of dataset on natural lightning flash initiation using three high-speed video cameras for the optically visible activity, combined with an array of seven electric field change (E-change) and Very High Frequency radio-band sensors for the electromagnetically detectable activity caused by rapid charge movements in lightning. The dataset is novel in three important ways: (1) Instead of targeting lightning flashes that connect to ground, this project targeted intracloud flashes, which typically occur first, last, and more frequently in thunderstorms. Intracloud flashes, and their initiation in particular, are more difficult to study because they start high and remain deep within obscuring cloud. (2) A more sensitive and faster frame-rate video camera was used, which allowed entire lightning flashes to be captured at 150,200 frames/second (image interval of 6.7 millionths of a second, or 6.7 microseconds). In addition to better light sensitivity for dim processes, the faster frame rates mean the luminosity development that occurs during each electromagnetic pulse can be discerned, which has not been possible before because the pulses occur so closely together in time. (3) The electromagnetic data collected at seven locations in north Mississippi allows for the individual pulse locations to be determined, and then these locations are used to determine spatial scaling of features in the video analyses. Combined, the unique dataset for over 200 flashes is very revealing.

The main analyses focused on the initial sparks, with obvious electromagnetic pulses that occur during the earliest few thousandths of a second (milliseconds) in lightning flashes. The intracloud flash initiating event detected in the electromagnetic data was accompanied by weak luminosity (less than 5% above background) that lasted for 300-500 microseconds, and was observed with both electromagnetically weak and powerful initiating events. Data from this project are the first that show there is visible light emitted during a specific type of powerful intracloud initiating event called a ?positive Narrow Bipolar Event.? Beginning a few milliseconds after the initiating event, a series of different breakdown events typically occur in the electromagnetic data of intracloud flashes. The luminosity of these events was much brighter than the initiating event, 10% to 360% above background, and each lasted for 520 ? 1750 microseconds. The new optical data for these breakdown events are evidence that the intracloud lightning channel forms intermittently at this early stage; the developing flash emits bright light when these pulses occur and is dark in the time between them. These results are the first evidence that intracloud flashes develop similarly, in this respect, to cloud-to-ground flashes. Overall, these observations provide real data supporting a recently published explanation of lightning initiation.

Tens of milliseconds after flash initiation, when intracloud lightning channels may have traveled far in the cloud, a few abrupt and large electromagnetic events sometimes occur. Such events were documented in this project and studied for comparison. Durations of bright luminosity were similar to early events, 700-1200 microseconds, but the later events were much brighter and more widespread in the cloud. Each of these distinct late events extended about 2.5 miles vertically upward, from below to above the flash starting point, and about 5.5-7 miles horizontally. Events of this sort are likely visible from satellite-borne optical lightning sensors, and the dataset from this project can help inform the spatial dimensions and optical details for newly available satellite data of lightning.

Another project objective was to obtain spectroscopic recordings of lightning flash initiation to determine the lightning channel temperature. In this objective, the project did not succeed, mainly because there were not enough thunderstorm opportunities in the single summer (2019) of data collection and further data collection was not possible in 2020 due to the pandemic. However, the fact that the project results on luminosity agree with a proposed physical mechanism indicates that spectroscopic recordings may not be essential for determining when the lightning channel becomes hot.

This project was important for the training of two graduate students pursuing Ph.D. degrees in physics, thereby augmenting the STEM workforce. A post-doctoral researcher gained experience developing new analysis tools for high-speed video camera data combined with electromagnetic sensor data.

Some results of this project are already disseminated in the peer-reviewed literature; other results have been presented and discussed at science conferences. In addition to adding to the knowledge base of lightning initiation, the results disseminated have already shaped investigations being conducted by other researchers in the field. These outcomes are expected to continue as additional results are published.
